newsitem.title: CHINA: Chang'an first-half net rises on sales.
newsitem.headline: Chang'an first-half net rises on sales.

text.p: China's Chongqing Chang'an Automobile Co Ltd said on Monday that expanded company sales and rising revenues from its joint venture with two Japanese carmakers buoyed first-half net profits.

The company, a leading maker of mini-cars based in the southwestern city of Chongqing, posted net profits of 125.91 million yuan ($15.2 million) for the first half, up 41 percent from the year-ago period based on international accounting standards.
"The company's sales increased rapidly in the first half and pushed up net profits," a company spokesman told the Hong Kong-based newsletter China Securities Bulletin.
Sales rose by 29.8 percent year-on-year to 1,434.61 million yuan in the first half, he said.
The company sold 42,618 vehicles, including 1,800 sedan cars, and 13,233 engines in the first six months, he said.
Chongqing Suzuki Automobile Co Ltd, a joint venture between Chang'an and two Japanese firms, sold 12,810 mini-cars in the first half, surging 90 percent year-on-year, he said.
Suzuki Motor Corp owns 35 percent of the venture with the remaining 15 percent held by Nisso Iwai Corp.

The venture, in which Chongqing Chang'an holds a 50 percent stake, reversed losses of 34 million yuan in the first half of 1996 to make a net profit of 30 million yuan in the first half of this year, the spokesman said.
Sales had risen sharply in major cities since the start of the year due to rising individual purchasing power, he said.
"The strong performance of the joint venture contributed revenue to our company," he said.
Chang'an would boost sales by upgrading after-sale services rather than by cutting prices in the second half, he said.
The company had 876.19 million outstanding shares at the end of June, including 120 million domestic A shares offered to the public in May and 250 million hard currency B shares.
Its per share net reached 0.144 yuan in the first half with net assets per share at 2.68 yuan. ($ = 8.289 Chinese Yuan)
